Two improvement solutions are presented to overcome reactive torque: coaxial axial dual magnetic suspension electromotive rotary wings and coaxial radial dual magnetic suspension electromotive rotary wings. Both solutions involve two independent magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing systems rotating in reverse directions, offsetting reactive torques and enhancing power performance.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to a process for spinning bast fibers, including twice health-preserving bast fibers and blended spinning bast fibers and other fibers. The process involves health-preserving bast fibers, opening, cleaning, and carding, drawing into strips, twice health-preserving, and spinning into yarn. The process reduces end breakage rate, improves work efficiency, and product quality. The invention also provides a bast fiber yarn and a multi-fiber yarn produced by this process.
</summary>

The invention relates to a method and apparatus for forming fiber mixtures from different fiber types by sequentially taking small partial quantities from each fiber bale. The method involves measuring the entire momentary quantity of each fiber bale before each pass of the bale opener, determining a certain partial quantity corresponding to a predetermined proportion of the momentary entire quantity, and continuously removing only the determined partial quantity from the measured fiber bale. The apparatus includes a bale opener, a quantity measuring device, and a control device that controls the mode of operation of the bale opener based on signals from the quantity measuring device. The control device may also include a timer to ensure that the partial quantity from each stored fiber lot is removed not later than by the end of a predetermined period.

<summary>
The invention relates to an improved process for the deacylation and desulfurization of a compound to produce a pyrazolotriazole, using hypophosphorous acid to reduce impurities and increase yield. The process involves reacting an acylated compound with an aqueous mixture of hypophosphorous acid and hydrochloric or hydrobromic acid to produce hydrogen sulfide and the desired pyrazolotriazole. The process is characterized by generating less sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities than when no hypophosphorous acid is present. The starting compound is a 3,6-disubstituted-7H-1,2,4-triazolo[3,4-b][1,3,4]thiadiazine, which is first reacted with an acylating agent to form an acylated intermediate. The process is suitable for preparing magenta couplers for photographic products. The use of hypophosphorous acid results in the formation of H2S by-product, which is readily removed, and does not reduce nitro groups or affect other functional groups in the molecule. The process is straight-forward, economical, and readily adaptable by industry. Two examples are provided to illustrate the process, with yields of 82% and 78% respectively. The process can be carried out in a continuous manner, as demonstrated in Example 3.
</summary>

The present invention relates to an improved method for producing 1,1,1-trifluoroethane (143a) by continuous gas phase hydrofluorination of 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane (142b) using heterogeneous catalysis. The organic feed is 142b and the fluorinating agent is HF. The process is carried out at a molar ratio of HF to 142b in excess of 1:1, preferably in excess of 2.5:1, in the presence of a Cr catalyst, which may be unsupported or supported, in the absence or presence of a cocatalyst selected from nickel, cobalt and manganese salts. The catalyst can be any (supported or unsupported) chromium salt, with CrF3.4H2O and Cr/Ni/AlF3 being preferred. The process is carried out at a temperature between 30° C. and 400° C., preferably between 30° and 280° C., more preferably between 100° and 250° C., more preferably between 120° C. and 200° C., with another preferred embodiment being between 280° and 350° C. Contact time can be varied from 1-100 seconds and is preferably between 5 and 15 seconds. The catalyst has to be activated first using nitrogen, air or HF/142b at a temperature between 100° C. and 650° C., preferably between 200° C. and 500° C. Hydrofluorination can be performed at a pressure between 1 atmosphere (0 psig) and 200 psig, preferably between 1 atmosphere and 150 psig. The molar ratio of HF to R142b can vary between greater than 1:1 and 20:1, preferably between greater than 1:1 and 10:1, more preferably between 2:1 and 5:1. Conversion is generally in excess of 99.5%, so that there is very little 142b in the effluent. The acids can be either scrubbed out by caustic washing or recovered by distillation. If distillation is used, a pressure distillation is needed to recover HCl with conventional refrigeration. The boiling point of HCl

The document describes a method and apparatus for forming melt spun nonwoven webs using non-eductive drawing. The system involves an initial quench chamber and a continuous two-dimensional slot across the entire machine width, which produces a linear plane of filaments in the slot impingement point section. The linear plane of filaments has substantially constant filament distribution across the machine width, providing good control of cross-machine uniformity. The process equipment is simple compared to both eductive and non-eductive systems, and the same air is used for both quenching the filaments and drawing them as it exits through the drawing impingement slot at high velocity.

<summary>
The invention is a buttonhole controlling device for sewing machines that ensures buttonhole stitching closes without overlap, regardless of the type of material being sewn.
The device includes a foot pad attached to a presser bar and a travelling assembly with an initial position defined by oppositely acting springs.
The travelling assembly moves with the work during buttonhole sewing and includes a slidable member positionable by a button for which a buttonhole is to be sewn.
This slidable member carries a tab to actuate a tripping lever on the machine, limiting the buttonhole length to that suitable for the inserted button.
An adjustable stop mounted on the travelling assembly engages the tripping lever to terminate buttonhole formation, allowing precise definition of the closure point.
The device compensates for different materials' slippage relative to the feed dog, preventing open or overlapping buttonholes.
The preferred embodiment is illustrated in the drawings and described in detail, with modifications possible without departing from the invention's spirit and scope as defined in the appended claims.
</summary>

<summary>
The text describes a fabric treatment apparatus that applies a liquid to a textile web, allows it to dwell for a certain time, and then removes the liquid along with any dirt or dye residues. The apparatus consists of a conveyor with an endless sieve belt, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch. The textile web is transported along a substantially horizontal path, with the liquid being applied at a first station and removed at a second station downstream of the first. The dwell stretch is disposed between the applicator and the suction device, conducting the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop. The apparatus is designed to lengthen the action time of the applied liquid on the substances to be removed from the fabric, improving the washing effect. It is particularly suitable for so-called "soilage washing" and can be used for treating knitted fabrics and printed materials without causing tension or smudges. The apparatus can have a compact construction and may include an air pass or a sieve drum for the dwell stretch.
</summary>

The present invention is a frame quilting machine that uses two separate computers to control the sewing machine functions and the quilting table movements independently, allowing for easier reprogramming of either function without affecting the other. The machine can accommodate both preprogrammed and individualized patterns, and includes a computer aided design program for creating and duplicating patterns. The quilting table can move in the X, Y, or X-Y direction, and the machine can sew patterns at high and low speeds.

<summary>
The invention is a combination electrical cord support and article holder, particularly useful for ironing boards. It supports the electrical cord of an electric iron above the ironing surface and holds articles like spray starch cans or beverage containers. The apparatus is mounted on the ironing board using a releasable clamp and includes a flexible cord support and a detachable article holder. The cord support has a first rod with a helical bent portion to receive the electrical cord, a coiled spring resilient section, and a second rod with a foot that pivots and slides within a brace on the clamp. The article holder has a lower hoop, support bars, an upper hoop with tangs, and vertical supports. It is detachably mounted to the clamp using a second brace with 'U' shaped bends that receive the tangs. The apparatus also includes an 'L' shaped bracket for mounting a female electrical outlet. The cord support can be retracted for storage, and the article holder can be removed from the clamp.
</summary>

The present invention relates to a method of making two-sided nonwoven fabrics with a durable three-dimensional image, suitable for various consumer applications. The method involves hydroentangling a layered precursor web comprising a first fibrous matrix on one side, a second fibrous matrix on the other side, and a fluid-pervious support layer or scrim in between, acting as a fiber distribution control layer. The precursor web is subjected to hydroentanglement on a moveable imaging surface having a three-dimensional image transfer device, imparting a three-dimensional image that is durable to abrasion and distortion due to elongation. The first and second fibrous matrices can be dissimilar, with the fibrous matrix having a lower fiber modulus coming in contact with the three-dimensional imaging transfer device. The support layer deters the fibrous constituents of the two outer layers from becoming excessively intermingled, resulting in a nonwoven fabric that exhibits sufficient resistance to delamination. The fabric can be further treated with performance or aesthetic modifying compositions to enhance durability, softness, and other desired properties.

The invention is a device for feeding a strip of material into a sewing machine and sewing it onto a cut of fabric, ensuring continuous operation and preventing damage to the needle when sewing relatively stiff strips. It features a stop that can be moved into the feed path of the strip, retracted after being contacted, and controls a signal transmitter for a setting means for the stop. The stop is mounted on a two-armed lever biased by a spring and can be adjusted by an air cylinder.

<summary>
The document describes a dry cleaning machine with an improved air flow system that minimizes solvent loss and prevents the escape of toxic solvent vapors when the door is opened. The machine has a separate intake fan and duct that draws ambient air into the access opening and directly into the interposed duct, with only a small amount of vapor commingling with the intake air and lost to atmosphere. The air flow system is isolated from the solvent vapors developed during the cleaning cycle by a normally closed valve, which opens only when the access door is opened. The machine also has a refrigeration system for solvent vapor recovery, which condenses the vapors in the condenser box and maintains the liquid solvent in the storage tank at a predetermined temperature. The refrigeration system has a single compressor that alternatively cools two distinct evaporator coils under either a continuously timed demand or a cyclical temperature responsive demand, with the time demand having precedent. The machine's control system includes a timer mechanism that controls the operation of the machine and a "cartridge dry" switch that allows the filters to be dried within the machine prior to being discarded. The control circuit includes a door switch that energizes the exhaust valve and exhaust door when the access door is opened, and a control box switch that indicates the termination of the cleaning cycle and allows the door to be unlocked.
</summary>

The sewing machine 1 can detect an ultrasonic wave transmitted from an ultrasonic pen 92 using three receivers 94, 95, and 96. The sewing machine 1 can calculate the specified coordinates E on the work cloth 100 that are specified using the ultrasonic pen 92 based on the detection timings T 2 of the receivers 94, 95, and 96. The sewing machine 1 can perform sewing based on the calculated specified coordinates E. The sewing machine 1 does not acquire the transmission timing T 1 of the ultrasonic wave. The ultrasonic pen 92 is not provided with an electromagnetic wave output circuit 921. The receiver 96 is provided on the left surface 17 of the pillar 12. The CPU 61 of the sewing machine 1 performs main processing to identify the specified position.

The invention describes a method for connecting two tape-shaped knit pieces using a flat knitting machine, where symmetrical loops of the final course of both pieces are overlaid and bound off gradually until the two pieces are connected. This method is used to link rope- or tape-shaped knit fabrics in various garments, such as sweater collars, tank top neck ropes, and baseball stocking lower ends, without the need for separate sewing processes.

<summary>
The invention relates to preparations for enhancing the utility of cellulosic fabrics, using wool particles or powder as carriers for functional additives like UV protection, anti-bacterial agents, or moisture management enhancers. The wool particles, preferably of macrofibril size or below, demonstrate exceptional carrying and retention ability for functional additives. The invention also includes methods of preparing and applying these preparations, and textile articles treated with them. The preparations can enhance the durability of functional enhancements in cellulosic fabrics, even after multiple washing cycles. The wool particles' helical structure and the damaged cuticle cells allow for better absorption and retention of functional additives. The invention also includes preparations using bamboo fiber powder for moisture management. The preparations can be applied using various methods, including printing, padding, or foam application. The treated fabrics show improved UV protection, wicking, wrinkle recovery, and anti-bacterial properties compared to untreated fabrics. The wool powder also enhances the wrinkle resistance of cotton fabrics.
</summary>

The invention presents a sewing machine detector that uses light shielding discs to detect needle position, speed, and thread trimmer timing, replacing the conventional reflective discs. This design reduces stress on optical fibers, improves durability against vibration, and simplifies manufacturing. Additionally, the detector employs an optical fiber for power indication, eliminating electrical interference with control circuitry.

The invention provides methods for producing silicon-based nanowires and films using liquid silane inks by electrospinning. Four-component inks containing a liquid silane, a polymer, an accelerant, and a solvent, and five-component inks containing an additional solid phase, are used to produce nanowires that are transformed into silicon-containing materials by thermal or laser processing. The nanowires can be used as components of composite materials such as electrodes for lithium ion batteries.

The invention relates to a rotary hook arrangement for a lockstitch sewing machine, aiming to minimize hindrance to the guiding and pull-back of the needle thread loop. The arrangement features a bobbin housing with a triangular shoulder on its loop cast-off side, and a spring rod and cams on the hook body. The shoulder and spring rod cooperate to control the rotation of the bobbin housing, while the cams prevent reverse rotation. A capsule release device can optionally provide a rotational impulse to the bobbin housing to further facilitate thread movement. The design ensures a jerk-free and low-friction motion of the needle thread loop, with or without the use of the capsule release device.

The invention relates to an arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel, featuring multiple spool holders, each with a brake rotor and an adjustable braking element. A tensioning lever, biased by departing threads, adjusts the braking element's position based on thread tension and weight. A fluid pressure-sensitive biasing arrangement, connected to each tensioning lever, allows for central control of thread tension across the entire creel. Additionally, a brake shoe can be employed for rapid braking upon machine shut-off.

The invention relates to a flexible traction element, production line, and method for embedding stranded cables in a flexible thermoplastic material. The traction element comprises stranded cables with a core strand sheathed in a flexible thermoplastic material layer. The production line includes a reel for unwinding the stranded cables, a device for precise orientation, a heater, an extruder for co-extrusion, a cooling trough, a roller store, a cutting device, and a storage roller. The method involves degreasing and preheating the stranded cables, and sheathing them in the extruder with the liquefied plastics material. The extruder has a thread guide for the stranded cables and at least one matrix, which can be adjusted with and in relation to one another individually, in a plane P angled with respect to the cable plane.

The invention describes a simplified process for continuously producing viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness. This process involves partially coagulating and drawing the yarn, completing the coagulation, washing it under specific conditions to reduce certain impurities, and then drying and finishing it. The washing step is crucial and must be done with water having a non-alkaline pH, reducing specific impurities to certain levels. The resulting yarn has a degree of white not lower than 45, measured by the Hunter method.

The present invention relates to a sensing roll for use in nip presses, which exerts pressing forces on webs for forming paper, textile material, plastic foil, and other related materials. The sensing roll is designed to measure and remove the effects of rotational variability from the nip pressure profile, allowing for a more accurate representation of the pressure distribution across the nip region. The sensing roll comprises strategically-placed sensors, including a first set of sensors disposed in a particular configuration along the roll cover and additional sets of sensors disposed in the same configuration but spaced apart circumferentially. Each sensor of the first set has a corresponding sensor in the additional sets, defining a cross-directional (CD) group of sensors that provide multiple pressure readings at each cross-directional position. The average of these readings is used to calculate and display the nip pressure profile, which is more accurate due to the cancellation or partial cancellation of rotational variability. The present invention also provides a method for sensing and removing the effects of rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of a sensing roll of a nip press, which includes providing a sensing roll with multiple cross-directional positions and placing pairs of pressure-measuring sensors at each cross-directional position. The method calculates an average pressure measurement at each cross-directional position and uses these measurements to provide a nip pressure profile for the nip press. The invention also includes a system for calculating and displaying a nip pressure profile and rotational variability profile for a nip press, which comprises a sensing roll configured with a second roll in a nip arrangement, the sensing roll having a plurality of cross-directional positions defined along its length and including a first set of pressure-measuring sensors and additional sets of pressure-measuring sensors disposed at each cross-directional position. The system also includes a processing unit for calculating the nip pressure distribution based on the pressure measurements of each CD group of corresponding sensors of the first and additional sets of sensors, and a display unit for providing a visual display of the nip pressure profile and the rotational variability profile.

The invention is a load-limiting device for dissipating energy during dynamic events, such as earthquakes, in structures like buildings. It is designed to undergo plastic deformation to limit the loads transmitted to other parts of the structure, preventing catastrophic failure. The device can be easily removed and replaced after plastic deformation. It is connected to the structure's brace using a connection means, which can be a high strength bolt, weld, adhesive bonding, clevis, shackle, or any other suitable means. The device can be checked for plastic deformation after a dynamic event using an indicator means, such as a brittle coat, mechanical device, or electronic sensor.

<summary>
The invention relates to biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composite materials with improved out-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio, designed using a function-oriented material design (FOMD) process and topology optimization. The BTR composite consists of stuffer members, tendon elements, and panels, which can be curved or flat, and can be arranged in various configurations. The stuffer members and tendon elements can be embedded in a matrix material, and the tendon elements can be tied or bonded at their crossing points to form joints. The BTR composite can be optimized for specific functions and loading conditions, and can be used in various applications, including military air vehicles, armor, and vehicular, aerospace, and marine body parts. The invention also includes methods for fabricating the BTR composite using bent-wire tendon elements and hollow stuffer members.
</summary>

The document describes a system and method for splicing a soil reinforcing element to extend its length in Mechanically Stabilized Earth (MSE) structures. The splice consists of wave plates with transverse protrusions that receive and seat corresponding transverse wires of the soil reinforcing element and a grid-strip, and a connective device that couples the wave plates and clamps down on the longitudinal wires, preventing removal.

<summary>
The document describes a system for deaerating oxygen-treated pulp before washing, addressing the challenge of vacuum loss and foam formation in washers. The proposed solution is a small, cylindrical deaeration tank with a tangential swirl-inducing inlet pipe, designed to be placed on top of or hung from the side of the oxygen reactor. The tank has an open top, flat bottom, and a nominal pulp slurry height of 0.8 times the tank diameter. The inlet pipe is located between the upper surface of the slurry and the top edge of the tank, allowing pulp to enter above the slurry surface and splash against the side wall. The outlet is located in the bottom plate of the tank, directly below the inlet pipe's outlet. The tank is swirled by filtrate from the washer, entering through a filtrate swirler inlet located between the bottom of the tank and the surface of the slurry. The system aims to maintain a pumpable consistency of 1-5% in the deaeration tank.
</summary>

The invention describes a safe with a unique door structure that can be easily assembled and is low-cost. The door is inserted at an angle and then slid into place, with a lockbolt engaging a detent to prevent lateral movement. Reinforcing bolts on both sides of the lockbolt protect the lock mechanism from forceful intrusion attempts.

<summary>
The document describes a plow blade with a water passageway, designed to reduce friction and power requirements during underground utility installation. The blade consists of multiple components, allowing for easy rebuilding and customization. Fluid is ejected at specific points along the blade through controlled flow paths, defined by voids and gaps between components. The location and size of these flow paths can be adjusted to match specific job requirements. The blade is manufactured using basic processes, making it less expensive to produce and maintain compared to previous designs. The invention is adaptable to both static and vibratory plowing utilities.
</summary>

The invention is a building system that allows for the creation of larger cladding areas without movement control joints, using a plaster matrix reinforced with mesh. The system complies with New Zealand building regulations and can resist wind speeds up to and including those associated with VH wind speed zones. The system is fixed to timber walls with studs at 600 mm centers and dwangs spaced at up to 900 mm centers. The weight of the total system is 41 kg/m2 and does not contribute to the building lateral bracing.

The present invention is a pulsed power device and method for Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR) using a combination of electrohydraulic (EH) and electromagnetic (EM) pulses to stimulate crude oil reservoirs. The device generates strong acoustic vibrations and coupled EM-acoustic vibrations that enhance oil flow and increase estimated ultimate recovery. The invention addresses the limitations of existing acoustic methods by using a multi-level discharge device that allows sequential firing of sources in one well or multiple wells to extend the effective range of stimulation. The device also includes EM pulse sources that do not generate a direct acoustic shock pulse, allowing for use in more sensitive wells. The invention further includes improvements to the EH discharge electrodes to reduce wear and increase efficiency. The recovered hydrocarbons are separated into their components, including associated gas, condensate, liquid hydrocarbons, helium and other noble gases, carbon dioxide, sulphur dioxide, pyrite, paraffins, heavy metals, and water.

The present invention relates to a portable, temporary guard rail support and assembly for use in erecting safety barriers at construction sites. The guard rail support consists of a flat bottomed base plate, an upright column, at least one guard rail support bracket, a kick board retaining flange, an angular brace, and a safety tie-off ring. The guard rail support can be anchored to a floor or ground surface using suitable fasteners. A concrete-filled steel base is also provided for use in circumstances where anchoring to a floor or ground surface is not possible. The steel base has a retaining groove for slidably receiving the base plate of the guard rail support and a channel for receiving at least one kick-board. A portable safety barrier can be constructed using at least first and second portable guard rail supports located in spaced relation to one another along a drop-off edge of a floor surface. The guard rail supports fixedly retain guard rails and kick boards within their respective brackets and retaining flanges. The guard rail support and assembly provide for easy installation and removal, reduce liability from inadequately reinstalled guard rails, and are durable for repeated use.

The lock device comprises an engaging member and an engaged member, allowing manual lock operation. The engaging member is a plate with a hook part and a slot, supported by a pin and guided by a member that touches either a first or second surface of the engaging member. The engaged member is a pin that engages with the hook part of the engaging member.

The invention is a swimming pool vacuum cleaner with an adjustable platform that allows precise regulation of suction efficiency during cleaning. The device has a central, vacuum portion that can be readily adjusted relative to the pool bottom using conveniently located adjustment mechanisms on the top of the suction head. The adjustment mechanisms regulate the spacing between the lower surface of the central, suction portion of the suction head and the bottom of the pool. The invention also includes a kit form of the adjustment mechanisms that can be interconnected with certain types of existing, prior art pool cleaning devices without the need for major retrofit of the existing devices.

The text describes a patent application related to monitoring and measuring fluid pressures in geological formations, specifically focusing on techniques that accurately measure pressure at a desired elevation without being influenced by pressures above or below the measurement point. The invention involves cementing a conduit with a filter at its bottom end in a borehole at a desired location, then pressurizing the conduit to clear it of cement grout during installation. Once the cement grout has set, a fluid is introduced into the conduit to displace the grout and create a fluid connection between the formation and the filter. In some cases, a hydrofracture process can be employed to ensure connectivity. The application discusses various embodiments, including one with a permanent downhole pressure transducer and another where the transducer is readily accessible from the surface. The invention aims to provide a more reliable connection system between the pressure sensing location within a cement grouted borehole and the transducer system used to monitor the pressure in the surrounding geological formation.

The text describes an apparatus for retrieving wear bushings from oil well drilling tools, which are used to protect against excessive wear in the well head and casing. The apparatus consists of a sub-unit with a mandrel and collars for mounting onto the drill string, and a retriever section that slides along the mandrel and engages with the wear bushing. The retriever section has protruding members that fit into slots on the wear bushing, allowing it to be retrieved by rotating the drill string. The apparatus is designed to allow vertical play of the retriever section to prevent damage to the wear bushing or the apparatus itself due to excessive weight below the retriever.

The invention relates to a jointing structure for vehicle traveling paths with an expansion function, useful for new transit systems, monorails, and road bridges. The structure comprises steps at the ends of coaxially built traveling paths with an expansion gap between, elastic members mounted inside the steps, and a joint block mounted on the elastic members across the expansion gap. The elastic members are designed to absorb bridge girder expansion or contraction caused by temperature changes or the like. The joint block blocks up the expansion gap, preventing tire fall-in and stuck-in situations while maintaining the expansion gap function. The structure is adaptable for various tire configurations, ensures high slip resistance, and is easy to maintain. A method of mounting the elastic members involves joining them together across the expansion gap, fixing one side to the step, deforming the fixed elastic member toward the bridge girder axis, and then fixing the other side to the step.

<summary>
The invention relates to a floor track system for transporting wheeled hand trucks in a sanitary fluid treatment chamber for food stuffs, preventing contamination of the treatment fluid by the truck wheels. The system consists of enclosed tracks that segregate the wheels from the chamber environment, allowing for the recovery and reuse of the brine solution. The tracks are supported above the chamber floor by legs, with a cover plate overlying the channel to prevent fluid entry. The cover plate can be pivoted for cleaning. Another embodiment uses inflatable seals around the truck's wheel struts to prevent fluid entry. The tracks are pitched to drain away liquid, and the system is well-suited for use with horizontally axled hand trucks. The invention aims to maintain the sanitary condition of the chamber and the recovered brine solution, while allowing for quick and versatile transportation of meat products. The enclosed track system prevents brine solution from becoming contaminated by the hand truck wheels, preserving natural resources and achieving economic advantages.
</summary>

The present invention is a downhole heating system for oil and gas wells to improve production by heating the oil and paraffin, focusing heat on the production zone, and protecting electrical components from well fluids. The system consists of production tubing, a heat insulating packer, perforated tubing, stainless steel collars, and a heating unit with electrical resistance heater rods. The heating unit's electrical connections are shielded using a cement block and steel fitting assembly to prevent invasion by conductive fluids and electrical shorts. The method of use involves installing the system to focus heat on the production formation and using cable instead of pipe for supporting the heating unit during well treatments or maintenance.

The invention presents a ladder attachment that improves stability and prevents damage to work surfaces. It features a brace with a resilient pad that pivots vertically or horizontally, allowing the ladder to straddle corners. The attachment increases the contact area with the work surface, reducing the risk of slipping or defacing the surface.

<summary>
The invention relates to a bedroom cabinet designed for use in flophouses, workmen's quarters, or stadiums. It aims to improve upon existing designs by providing a cabinet with a flat external surface and internal space for user belongings and devices without compromising the dwelling area.
The cabinet is composed of an outer casing and an inner casing, with the outer casing having an upper and lower portion, each with front, rear, left, right, upper, and lower surfaces integral to each other.
The front surface of the upper outer casing has a notch corresponding to the upper half of an exit, while the lower outer casing has a notch corresponding to the lower half of the exit.
The inner casing consists of a front panel, back panel, left and right side panels, a ceiling panel, and a bottom panel, with the front panel having an opening in communication with the notches of the upper and lower outer casings.
The bottom panel has a mat on its surface, and the peripheral edges of the upper and lower outer casings have outwardly projected flanges that abut each other when assembled.
The cabinet is designed to be strong and soundproof, with a clearance between the outer and inner casings used to form boxes for electric devices or user belongings, and to house wirings.
In a further embodiment, a clearance is formed over the whole periphery between the outer and inner casings, with spacer members interposed in the clearance to form a uniform air flow passage for natural ventilation and increased sound-proofing.
The cabinet can be assembled by first fitting the inner casing into the lower outer casing, then fitting the upper outer casing, and securing them together with clip members and an ornamental web.
The cabinet can accommodate a TV receiver, an interphone, and other devices, with wiring work easily achievable under the condition that the inner casing is fitted and fixed within the lower outer casing.
In the second embodiment, a sheet covering the mat can be wound on one roller by rotating winding rollers in one direction, allowing for easy replacement of the sheet.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention pertains to precast concrete retaining walls, specifically for use alongside highways and railways. It aims to address the limitations of prior art retaining walls, such as the need for excessive excavation, the use of cast-in-place bases, and the lack of counterforts for support. The invention provides a retaining wall system comprising a precast, solid base and a precast face panel with integral counterforts. The base and face panel are connected using a grouted rebar connection, eliminating the need for temporary shoring. The system allows for taller walls and shorter bases, reducing installation and transportation costs. It also offers flexibility in customizing the height and width of the individual components. Additionally, the system can include H-piles for added stability in poor soil conditions and cast-in-place or pre-cast vehicle impact barriers.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to downhole vibratory tools designed to dislodge stuck objects (fish) and transmit pulling force in deviated wellbores. Unlike previous designs, this tool allows for wireline access through its central passage when not in use, thanks to an annularly disposed dump valve that doesn't block the center. The tool is activated by dropping a simple, retrievable plug into the passage, which seals its lower end. The tool's power is enhanced by stacking pistons in the tool body, increasing the delivered power per stroke. The tool can be operated to deliver high amplitude, low frequency oscillating forces with or without impacts, depending on how it's operated by rig personnel. The tool's design reduces wear on the dump valve by avoiding impacts on a seat, and allows the mandrel to continue moving downhole after the valve opens, keeping forces in phase with the oscillating string or fish. The tool can also be used for stimulation or fishing operations and may include a rotational lock for torque transmission.
</summary>

The document describes a light member for aquarium use, featuring a housing with a lighting control region that includes multiple control channels for different colored lights. The light member can accommodate interchangeable light-emitting modules, each with electrical connectors that couple to specific control channels, allowing users to customize the lighting output.

The invention describes a desmodromic valve actuation system for internal combustion engines, eliminating the need for springs and allowing for variable valve displacement. The system uses a rotating cam to drive a reciprocating slide, which in turn controls the valve position through a rotating link with a slotted cam. The valve displacement can be adjusted incrementally from zero to its maximum value, allowing for precise control of the valve opening and closing.

The invention presents a system for controlling a fuel delivery device in a vehicle, capable of switching between automatic and manual control. The automatic mode optimizes fuel efficiency and reduces emissions, while the manual mode allows full vehicle operation. The system ensures a smooth transition between modes by matching the throttle valve position with the accelerator pedal command before switching.

<summary>
The document discusses improvements to composed stave floors, also known as engineering floors, which consist of a base substrate (core) and a sight substrate (finished face or top part). The existing floors have issues such as thin sight substrate thickness leading to deformation and detachment upon sanding, and problems with joining the substrates using only glue. The example embodiment aims to preserve the physical, aesthetic, and functional properties of the sight substrate, prevent deformation, bond both sheets without displacement or change of dimensions, provide a longer useful life with corrective maintenance, and improve the glaze application. The method involves using a sight substrate with a thickness of at least 4 mm, a base substrate with a thickness of at least 12 mm, and multidirectional holding means consisting of dendrites, glue, and clamps or cemented clamps. The example embodiment demonstrates that the improved floor does not exhibit deformation or detachment, allows for corrective maintenance, and provides increased durability compared to conventional floors.
</summary>

The provided text describes a position sensor system that uses a waveform generator and an error correction generator to modify a sensing signal, removing unnecessary power and providing the signal to a remote monitor via two wires for multiplexing multiple sensors. The error correction generator determines and eliminates strong static signals and error signals that do not deliver information about the position of an object being sensed, constantly comparing the sensor output to a desired minimum value and generating a correction signal to deliver a sensor output close to the desired minimum. The system is designed to operate with minimal energy consumption, drawing a minimum of current upon startup and initial calibration, and can be recalibrated at any time by external means.

The present invention pertains to collated fasteners, specifically a collated nail strip formed with a debris-free plastic material for use in a fastener driving tool. The strip consists of nails arranged at an angle to the transverse direction, held together by a plastic collation system. The plastic material is an adhesive polymer, such as a maleic anhydride modified polypropylene, that adheres to the nails and penetrates the substrate with the nail, reducing debris generation. The strip is configured to minimize corrugation and flexing, and to encourage separation of the nails from the strip at a desired location to further reduce debris. Various configurations, such as notches, thinned regions, and tapered connecting portions, are used to influence separation location and minimize debris. The strip can also include formations on the nail shanks to facilitate penetration of the collation material into the substrate.

<summary>
The invention is a nozzle for applying sealants like silicones, used in various industries such as aviation, automotive, naval, railway, and robotics. It consists of a bell-shaped lower section coupled to an injection button with a specific design. The nozzle can be connected to sealant cartridges or injection machines, facilitating the injection of sealants in multiple industrial applications. The bell-shaped section allows for encapsulation of rivets or screws, particularly useful in the aeronautical industry. The injection button, coupled to the bell-shaped section, has a special design with channels and orifices that guide the injection of sealant around rivets and nuts, improving encapsulation and providing an optimum seal. The nozzle can be used both manually and by automated sealant injection machines, adding versatility to its use. The nozzle is preferably made of plastic, such as polypropylene, and its structure is designed to be strong and durable. The nozzle simplifies the sealing work, reduces sealant application time, and increases the quality of the resulting sealant application.
</summary>

The invention presents a lightweight point cap system for attaching arrow points to shafts, reducing stress on the shaft, and preventing dirt from entering. It also includes a balance pin to adjust arrow weight and balance. The point cap and balance pin can be used together for precise balancing, and the point cap can be replaced if damaged, saving the more expensive arrow shaft.

<summary>
The text describes an evaporative cooling system that separates the dry and wet sides of a heat exchanger to cool air without adding water vapor. The system recirculates air from the enclosure to be cooled as the working fluid on the wet side, maximizing the temperature differential and efficiency. A specific embodiment uses an array of vertically directed hollow tubes for countercurrent flow of water and air, with fresh air passing through externally for cooling. The system can also include heat exchange between the moist return air and fresh air, or a hybrid system with a vapor compression refrigeration unit to dehumidify a portion of the cooled air. The apparatus is more efficient and energy-saving than traditional vapor compression refrigeration units.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention is a waste fuel burner that emits minimal particulate materials, operates with little slag or clinkers, can burn wet wood, is self-regulating, and has fast response times. It consists of a primary combustion chamber with a conical pile of waste fuel, fed from below with preheated underfire air, and a secondary combustion chamber with secondary combustion air introduced tangentially. The primary chamber operates below stoichiometric proportions to maintain temperatures lower than the melting point of ash, while the secondary chamber operates above stoichiometric proportions for complete combustion. A flame holder in the throat of the primary chamber prevents particulate matter from entering the secondary chamber. The burner can also be used to burn dirty, particulate-laden combustible gas. The control system adjusts the air and wood feed rate based on BTU demand, and trims the swirl and secondary air quantities based on temperature or oxygen level. The underfire air is preheated and its flow is controlled based on pressure drop across an inlet orifice.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to downhole tools for conducting mechanical activities in wells, specifically a simply and efficiently operable mechanism for installing and removing objects in wells, including those that might be stuck or lost within a well bore.
The mechanism is an improvement over a previous patent (U.S. Pat. No. 4,061,389) and promotes effective connection of a pull tool to a downhole object or fish and simple and effective disconnection of the pull tool from the object if desired.
During drilling operations, well servicing operations, and the like, objects may become lost or stuck within a well bore and these objects are typically referred to as "fish."
Many different types of pull tools, grappling devices, spears, etc. have been developed for the purpose of conducting fishing operations in well bores, often using wire line operations.
In many cases, downhole devices are positioned within casing and tubing strings for the purpose of controlling well operations, and such downhole devices are often equipped with API Standard fishing necks.
However, these fishing necks may become corroded or eroded by well conditions to the point that only a stub pipe is exposed without the usual undercut shoulder that is provided on the fishing neck.
Connection between a wire line controlled fishing tool and a worn fishing neck may be accomplished by means of an overshot type grappling device generally defined by a collet structure having internal teeth that establish a gripping relation with the worn fishing neck.
Although overshot type retrieving tools are successfully utilized in many cases, a common problem with such tools is the inability of the operator to achieve disconnection from the worn fishing neck in the event the tool is unable to accomplish an effective pulling operation.
Occasionally, disconnection can be achieved by a substantial jarring or other violent mechanical movement, but, in some cases, disconnection of the pulling tool from the fish is extremely difficult if not impossible.
</summary>

<summary>
The document describes a mounting link assembly for connecting an engine to a gearbox, designed to withstand extreme loads such as those caused by fan blade-off events. The assembly includes a male link and a female link that allow for translation relative to each other, with a radial interface providing coulomb damping to dissipate energy. A pin selectively retains the links and is designed to shear at a known load magnitude, preventing damage to the gearbox and its attached peripherals while helping to prevent detachment from the engine. The assembly limits damage and prevents detachment by absorbing extreme loads and dissipating energy through the radial interface.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to a fluid pump comprising multiple pump heads arranged in series, each containing an impeller driven by a common drive structure. Fluid flows sequentially through each pump head, with the initial pump head drawing fluid from a reservoir and the final pump head expelling fluid. The drive structure passes through the inlet between pump heads, connecting the impellers and permitting common driving. The pump heads may be removably connected or formed in a unitary structure, with intermediate pump heads having design features of both initial and final pump heads. The fluid pump cannot be constructed by simply stacking known pumps together, requiring unique design features for fluid flow and common driving of impellers. A pump assembly comprises the fluid pump mounted on a support structure, such as a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer. The support structure permits operation of the pump at a fluid reservoir, with the pump drawing fluid from the reservoir and discharging it into a desired location.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to an air intake device for an internal combustion engine that improves engine performance and reduces intake noise. The device comprises a tank with two pipes connecting it to the intake passage, one with a larger cross-section and a valve, and the other with a smaller cross-section. The valve opens or closes based on engine load conditions. The larger pipe improves dynamic effects, while the smaller pipe acts as a resonator to reduce noise. The valve is controlled to open or close at specific engine speeds and loads to maximize performance. The device is designed to minimize the length of the air inlet pipe upstream of the air cleaner to enhance dynamic effects while keeping noise within permissible levels.
</summary>

The invention describes a mixing valve for an aircraft cleaning apparatus, capable of combining fluids from two separate sources (soap solution and water) into one mixture, ranging from 0% soap solution, 100% water to 100% soap solution, 0% water. The valve system allows continuous analog control of the proportional quantities of the two fluids, ensuring constant pressure cleaning solution to each user.

<summary>
The invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for high-temperature fluid-flow machines, specifically a cooled stator blade or rotor blade for a gas turbine. The apparatus is designed to operate in ambient temperatures above the maximum permissible material temperature, and uses internal cooling channels to reduce the metal temperature to a required level. The apparatus comprises a blade airfoil section with cooling channels running in the longitudinal direction, through which a cooling fluid flows. The cooling fluid flows along the insides of the hot-gas walls, providing a cooling effect, and then emerges to the outside through film-cooling openings. The cooling channels are separated by separating walls, which also act as deflection devices to ensure that the cooling fluid flows successively through adjacent cooling channels in alternately opposite directions. The separating walls and deflection devices are no longer cast together with the apparatus but are constructed as separate inserts, which are subsequently inserted into the apparatus and secured there. This approach avoids the disadvantages of the known apparatus, such as the difficulty to cool the transitional region from the hot-gas wall to the separating wall, thermal stresses between the separating wall and the hot-gas wall, high blade weight leading to high centrifugal-force stresses, and complex casting development. The use of inserts composed of metal or non-metal materials allows for a more flexible cooling system that can be easily adjusted by replacing the inserts. The flow deflection apparatus is preferably a blade in a gas turbine, with the cooling channels and separating walls extending essentially in the radial direction with respect to the rotation axis of the gas turbine. The inserted separating walls are connected by an integral material joint, preferably by soldering or welding, to the blade, with the joint arranged at the end of the separating walls close to the axis. The invention simplifies the production of the apparatus, reduces its weight, and improves its cooling efficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to engine compression release brakes, specifically for engines with less than all cylinders equipped with brakes. Traditional systems have a brake for each cylinder, but this invention reduces components by using brakes on only a portion of cylinders. The engine includes an engine housing defining multiple cylinders, with an engine compression release brake for each of a portion of the cylinders, less than all. A method of engine braking involves attaching an engine compression release brake to an engine housing for a portion of the engine cylinders, then operating that portion in a braking mode. The engine compression release brake is operably coupled to a cam actuated exhaust valve. The engine braking system includes a low pressure reservoir, a high pressure pump, a high pressure manifold, and an electronic control module. Each cylinder has a movable piston and is operably connected to a fuel injector and a cam actuated exhaust valve. A portion of the cylinders also include a hydraulically actuated engine compression release brake connected to the exhaust valve. The engine compression release brake has a brake body, an electrical actuator, a spool valve member, and a piston. The electrical actuator controls the spool valve member, which in turn controls the piston. The piston moves a lash adjuster, which opens the exhaust valve for engine braking. The invention is modular, allowing customers to choose the amount of braking horsepower they desire for a specific application.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to minimizing flow disturbances in turbines during periodic operational testing of control valves. It uses control valve positions as feedback to maintain constant total mass flow and minimize steam boiler pressure changes or turbine power changes. The method calculates total mass flow for N parallel flow valves based on control valve position and compensates for flow changes when one valve is closed for testing. The system uses a test compensation circuit and a test control circuit for each valve, with the test compensation circuit adjusting flow through parallel control valves to minimize flow disturbance. The invention was successfully tested on a simulated turbine system, reducing pressure excursion by 95% compared to a test without flow compensation.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention is a two-part bracket system for mounting speakers or other equipment to various surfaces, including poles, flat surfaces, and walls. The system consists of a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket. The stationary bracket is mounted on the surface, while the adjustable bracket is attached to the equipment. The adjustable bracket is designed to be easily connected and disconnected from the stationary bracket, allowing for simple and efficient installation by a single person. The system also includes pole adapters for mounting on poles, and a speaker mounting bracket for attaching speakers. The brackets are made of stainless steel to resist weather, wind, and vibration, making them suitable for outdoor use. The system is designed to be resistant to rotation and slippage, and can accommodate a wide variety of pole shapes and sizes. The adjustable bracket allows for easy aiming and adjustment of the mounted equipment, and can be securely fastened in place with screws. The system is designed to be economical and efficient, using a minimal amount of robust components.
</summary>

<summary>
The text discusses the challenges in cooling rotary internal combustion engines, particularly the hot spots around spark plugs. It introduces an invention that aims to improve cooling and reduce thermal distortion by staggering spark plug bosses in the cooling circuit, allowing for better heat transfer and controlled flow. The invention involves offsetting spark plug bosses in the direction of flow, using flow diverters, and ensuring close in-line arrangement of spark plug terminals. The preferred embodiment shows a rotary engine with two staggered spark plug bosses in the cooling passage, improving heat transfer by up to 44% compared to an in-line arrangement. The offset of spark plug terminals from the trochoid wall centerline is crucial and should be less than the radius of a boss to achieve the benefits of the invention.
</summary>

<summary>
The document describes a system for mounting cooling fans to an enclosure without using fasteners, aiming to reduce costs and labor. The system involves a motor carrier with resilient legs that snap into place on a panel, using a combination of compression and rotation forces. The legs have turned-out portions that fit into recesses on the panel, and spring members urge the motor carrier away from the panel to prevent vibration. The system is applicable in various industries where forced air cooling is necessary.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention is a Small Arms Firing Effect Simulator (SAFES) for military training, simulating the sound and flash of live ammunition without modifying the weapon or using blanks.
The SAFES uses an electrical ignition system to ignite pyrotechnic charges in a confined space, venting the combustion through the weapon's ejection port.
The device is designed for use with the M16 rifle and interfaces with the weapon's trigger and bolt, providing automatic and semiautomatic fire modes.
The pyrotechnic charges are housed in an expendable plastic housing, containing a plurality of rounds, and are ignited in sequence by firing control circuitry.
The electrical control circuit consists of ten functional blocks, including a bolt interface, trigger interface, oscillators, firing counter, firing decoder, firing control, and firing sensors.
The bolt interface simulates operator actions by engaging the weapon's bolt and inhibiting pyrotechnic charges from firing when the weapon is out or the bolt is open.
The trigger interface detects trigger action and provides signals to the oscillator control circuit and the 10 Hertz oscillator.
The oscillator control circuit enables the 500 Hertz oscillator based on trigger and bolt actions, providing CLK signals for firing counter and decoder.
The firing counter and decoder work together to sequence through the pyrotechnic charges, enabling two SCRs at a time to control current flow through one charge.
The firing sensor detects the moment a charge fires and resets the oscillator control flip-flop, turning off the 500 Hertz oscillator.
The MILES interface provides a signal to the MILES unit associated with the weapon at the moment a charge fires.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to a method and arrangement for compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas. The method involves compressing the gas to a higher pressure, cooling it by heat exchange, and then expanding it to the desired exit pressure while further cooling it to the required exit temperature. The arrangement includes compressors, heat exchangers, valve-controlled pipelines, and an electronic control system. During summer operation, the gas is compressed in three stages, with a predominant portion of the compression occurring in two primary stages, and the excess pressure is reached in an additional compression stage. The gas is then cooled and expanded in an expansion turbine, which is coupled to the booster compressor. During winter operation, the compressors of the second primary compression stage are operated in parallel with the compressors of the first primary compression stage. The invention aims to reduce investments and operation risk by eliminating the need for conventional re-cooling plants.
</summary>

<summary>
The present disclosure relates to a combustion apparatus, specifically a burner that can be part of a system including interchangeable heat utilizing appliances. The burner is designed to optimize efficiency and limit unburned fuel emissions when using solid fuels like firewood or charcoal briquettes. It has a combustion chamber enclosed by an outer wall surrounding a fuel holder, with air flowing through the fuel holder to support initial combustion and around the fuel holder to support secondary combustion. A shroud provides a second wall, establishing a flow path for tertiary combustion air and providing an external surface cool enough to avoid burns. The burner has legs holding the combustion chamber above ground level and a pivotally coupled ash pan. A perforate food grate is pivotally coupled to the burner and can be moved to a deployed position above the flame or a stowed position to the side of the combustion chamber. Opposite the food grate, a cover is pivotally coupled to the burner to close the combustion chamber and prevent the ingress of dropped items, exposure to heat and exhaust fumes, and the escape of live embers. The burner has manual couplings for removably coupling modular heat utilizing appliances, including closed and open cookers, a food smoker, a space heater, and a pyrolyzer. The burner's nature will become more apparent upon further review of the following specification and drawings.
</summary>

The invention relates to a large-scale oil shear type clutch unit used in aircraft catapult systems, featuring separate piston and cylinder means for each clutch disc segment to minimize residual drag, auxiliary fluid pressure control for retraction and cooling, and easily removable clutch disc segments for maintenance without complete disassembly. The clutch unit is controlled by a servo control valve and fluid amplifiers, providing accurate fluid pressure control for various input conditions. The clutch unit comprises interleaved clutch plates and discs, with the discs segmented for easy removal and replacement, and supported by bushings and rings that allow for axial play and convenient inspection.

<summary>
Spacecraft structures require lightweight, stiff composite materials, but these lack inherent damping, leading to high vibration levels that compromise functionality. Precision kinematic mounts (KM) used for instruments have little inherent damping, exacerbating vibration issues during flight. Current efforts to reduce vibration through graphite structure modifications may not be sufficient. The invention aims to provide kinematic mounts with novel damping features and a passive energy dissipating mechanism to protect instruments from damaging flight loads. The mounts use six identical strut elements to reduce manufacturing complexity and costs, and can be incorporated into existing KM structures. The damping mechanism is provided at machined hinge or flexure locations of the mounts, with two preferred damper designs: a spherical damper and a cylindrical slot damper. These dampers dissipate vibration energy into heat, reducing high energy disturbances to the instrument. The invention also proposes alternative damped KM design concepts, such as truss structures or a set of three damped mounts, with the option to arrange the mounts to approximately uncouple the suspension modes, further improving KM performance.
</summary>

The invention relates to a rolling body guide cage produced from a ring element composed of at least two flat material ring segments joined and welded together in succession in the circumferential direction. The ring segments are preferably 120° segments punched out from a sheet metal strip, reducing waste material. The cage can be used for radial or axial bearings, including groove and angular ball bearings. The method for manufacturing the cage involves welding the ring segments together before forming the cage's axial profiling and rolling body guide structures.

The present invention provides a system for assessing and comparing radiation therapy segmentations from different sources, such as clinicians or autosegmentation software, using a metric method that evaluates the conformance between the three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing the structure defined by the first and second electronic files. The system generates volume models from the segmentation files, compares them to identify common, missing, and extra volume elements, and measures the conformance based on a metric method that can be customized by the user.

<summary>
The provided text describes a system and method for obtaining and using location information, specifically latitude and longitude coordinates, to improve customer service in a telecommunications network. The system involves a service technician using an input device to access a technician server, which can request and obtain coordinates from a global satellite positioning system (GPS). The coordinates are then used to update databases associated with the customer's service location, enabling more efficient and effective customer service. Additionally, the system can generate travel directions for a service technician to travel from one customer service location to another using the obtained coordinates. The system aims to reduce driving time and improve response time by providing accurate service location information.
</summary>

The invention describes an internal combustion engine with multiple cylinders, including combustion cylinders and expansion cylinders, which work together to capture and utilize heat energy from the exhaust gas. The expansion cylinders are designed to have a larger displacement and surface area than the combustion cylinders, allowing them to cool the exhaust gas and water to a low temperature, potentially eliminating the need for a radiator. The engine also incorporates water injection and recovery systems, as well as catalytic materials to reduce exhaust emissions.

The invention describes the use of thin substrate waveguides, optically coupled to a coherent light source like a laser, as an improved method for controlled illumination of objects such as holograms and spatial light modulators. These waveguide holograms offer high diffraction efficiencies, compact size, and reduced stray light, but may require compensation for non-uniformity and alignment sensitivity.

<summary>
The invention relates to accelerating floating point operations in data processing systems, specifically focusing on the effective subtraction operation. It improves upon the related art by dividing the effective subtraction operation into two procedures based on the absolute value of the difference in the arguments of the exponents of the two operands. When the absolute value of the difference is less than or equal to one, the alignment of the fractions and the subtraction can be performed simultaneously, reducing the number of steps. When the absolute value of the difference is greater than one, the subtraction operation is performed to ensure a positive result, and the normalization and rounding steps are combined into a single step. The invention also introduces the use of a subset of the operand exponent arguments to initiate the subtraction operation before the complete difference is known, further accelerating the process.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention provides a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields using two real triaxial magnetic field sensors, three pairs of compensation coils, and a control unit. The system can handle both homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields, simulate measuring electromagnetic interfering fields at the location of the object to be protected, and equalize feedback effects when using two magnetic field compensation systems in immediate vicinity. The control unit combines the six output signals of the two real sensors into three output signals of a virtual sensor using a freely definable kind of averaging. The averaging is described by a matrix multiplication, and the output signals of the virtual sensor are used as inputs for independent control loops operating in parallel. The control loops have control algorithms transforming the virtual input signals into changed signals, and the changed signals are multiplied by a matrix to obtain control signals for the six coils. If two compensation systems are operated directly beside each other, the feedback between the two systems is described by a feedback, or crosscoupling matrix C, and the matrix of the output signals of the real sensors is enlarged to a 6×1 matrix Ŝ. The control signals are calculated using the relation O=L·Ω(M·(S−C·O)).</summary>

<summary>
The document describes a voice-activated distance measuring device for golfers, using GPS technology and voice recognition to provide distance and other information verbally. The device can be incorporated into headgear like a hat or visor, with a bone conductance vibration sensor for clear voice pickup and noise rejection. It can also predict golf strategy based on user performance data, provide pre-recorded golf instructions, and be used for other applications like hiking or hunting. The device can communicate with a separate computer for data upload/download, course database management, and voice recognition command training. It uses Bluetooth technology for data transfers, audio server/client functions, short-range audio communications, and remote GPS. The device can also record and share geographic coordinates of golf courses for distance calculations and advice.
</summary>

The invention relates to a method for investigating a sample derived from a biological source using CARS microscopy. The method involves generating a resonance signal by coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering upon excitation of at least one resonance site of the sample by means of laser irradiation, sensed in image-producing fashion. The method comprises furnishing at least one resonance site by means of a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure of the sample with at least one reaction partner. The bioorthogonal reaction can be a Diels-Alder reaction or a Staudinger ligation, and can involve a modified Huisgen cycloaddition, nitrone dipolar cycloaddition, norbornene cycloaddition, (4+1) cycloaddition, or oxanorbornadiene cycloaddition. The method can also involve a copper-free click reaction using cyclooctynes, a tetrazine reaction, a tetrazole reaction, or a quadricyclane reaction. The at least one intrinsic structure of the sample can be equipped with a resonance site by means of the bioorthogonal reaction, and the non-resonant background of the sample can be furnished with resonance sites and correlated with a signal component attributable to intrinsic resonance sites of the sample. The method allows for dedicated detection of target sites in samples without negatively affecting biochemical processes, and enables the CARS-active scattering cross section of the respective target to be increased or generated.

The present invention relates to a method and system for tracking specimens acquired from patients in a medical facility, aiming to reduce or eliminate mislabeling of specimen vials. The method involves using unique machine-readable codes, such as barcodes, on identification means worn by patients and specimen-takers, on orders, and on specimen containers. The system comprises a standalone or networked computer in operative communication with a computer storage and an electronic reading means, such as a barcode scanner. The computer stores the machine-readable codes in a relational manner in a database data structure, ensuring that the patient, order, specimen-taker, and specimen container are all related to the same patient. The system generates signals to acquire specimens and places them in the appropriate containers, and stores an indication of the specimen collection time in the computer storage. The system also verifies the expiration date of the specimen containers and alerts the user if a container is out-of-date. The invention provides a failsafe, zero-defect process for identifying and processing patient specimen samples, eliminating the need for vial labels and associated printers, and reducing staff labor.

<summary>
The present invention is a remote control system and algorithm for supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) enabling navigation and automatic operation of a mobile energy recovery system. The system optimizes efficiency by accounting for data from weather observations and sensors on the mobile structure, relating these data points to performance models for the mobile structure itself. The mobile structure can be a sailing or propelled vessel or barge, or any mobile buoyant energy recovery system known by one of ordinary skill in the art. The SCADA system includes computer servers that gather data through diverse means such as Global Position Satellite (GPS) systems, weather satellite systems, and various geographic and weather data resources. The SCADA computer servers run Human Machine Interface (HMI) secure software applications which communicate to microprocessor systems running client software with a Graphical User Interface (GUI) to allow remote humans to optionally interact and choose mission critical navigation plans. The system is not limited to implementation of a specific mobile structure and applies to remote control of any system that exploits energy from weather patterns that avail formidable amounts of naturally occurring energy. The system comprises an algorithm that optimizes energy extraction using yield functions derived from weather and geospatial data and vessel performance models, and can also guide navigation of vessels for logistics-only purposes past such weather patterns.
</summary>

<summary>
The present invention provides a method for design rule checking in semiconductor design technology, specifically for integrated circuits (ICs) that include both logic and memory circuits. The method involves creating customized design rules for different types of memory regions by modifying standard logic rules to accommodate more liberal memory-based parameters. These customized rules are then used to check the mask pattern data of the IC, ensuring that the right set of rules is applied to the right regions. The method helps eliminate false errors caused by applying logic rules to memory regions and accurately pinpoints real design rule errors. It also categorizes the results based on the region where the error occurred, such as in Logic, Bordered Single Port (BDSP) SRAM, Borderless Single Port (BLSP) SRAM, Dual Port (DP) SRAM, and ROM groups. The invention is applicable to any mask pattern database, including those with no memory blocks or multiple types of memory blocks.
</summary>

The invention concerns the fabrication of plates or blanks of coated steel intended to be welded and then heat treated to obtain parts having good mechanical characteristics and good corrosion resistance. The fabrication method described in patent EP 0971044 can be applied to butt-welded blanks, but this method runs into difficulties: when welding coated steel blanks, a portion of the initial surface pre-coating is transferred into the molten area created by the welding operation, forming intermetallic areas that reduce the overall deformability of the welded joints after heat treatment. The present invention provides a solution to this problem by removing the metal alloy layer of the precoat in an area at the periphery of the plate, on at least one precoated face of the plate. The width of the area from which the metal alloy has been removed is preferably between 0.2 and 2.2 mm. The invention also provides a method of fabricating a precoated steel plate that includes coating a steel plate to obtain a precoat having an intermetallic alloy layer topped by a metal alloy layer, on at least one face of the plate, removing the metal alloy layer in an area not totally contiguous with the periphery of the plate and cutting the plate in a plane so that the area from which the metal alloy has been removed is at the periphery of the cut plate. The invention further provides a welded blank obtained by butt-welding at least two plates according to the invention, the welded joint being produced on the edge contiguous with the area from which the metal alloy has been removed. The invention also provides a part obtained by heat treatment and deformation of a welded blank according to the invention, the precoat being converted throughout its thickness by the heat treatment into an intermetallic alloy compound providing protection against corrosion and decarburization of the steel substrate. The invention also provides a use of a plate, blank or part according to the invention for the fabrication of structural or safety parts for motorized terrestrial automotive vehicles.

<summary>
The invention relates to implementing a FIFO queue in a functional memory using a tree-shaped data structure. The queue is maintained by adding data units to the first non-full node on the first edge of the tree and deleting data units from a leaf node on the opposite edge. The tree is balanced and filled according to specific conditions. A header node can be added to improve performance and enable queue inversion in constant time and space. The queue can be used as a double-ended queue, and the inversion bit can be used in the basic embodiment without a header node.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to electrically programmable read-only memory (EPROM) devices, particularly embedded EPROMs manufactured using existing integrated circuit (IC) technologies. Current EPROMs are manufactured using specialized technologies, making it impractical to integrate them with other IC types like DRAM or logic circuits. The invention aims to provide practical methods for building embedded EPROMs using existing IC manufacturing technologies, specifically targeting DRAM redundancy circuits and standard logic technologies. The primary objectives are to create EPROM devices that can be manufactured using existing DRAM technology and standard logic technologies, without requiring high voltages for operation.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to an improved identification card containing an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip, protected by being laminated between two shock-absorbing, non-rigid layers, which are then encased between two rigid outer layers. The card is designed to protect the electronic components from damage caused by bending or external stresses, unlike prior art cards which used rigid materials throughout. The core layer and bottom sheet are made of silica-filled polyolefin, with the antenna and chip sandwiched between them and secured by adhesive layers. The card also includes alkyd resin spids containing an anti-binding agent, printed on the core layer to support the antenna. The core layer and bottom sheet are encased between two laminate layers, providing structural support and protection. The card can be personalized with variable indicia using dye diffusion thermal transfer or inkjet printing methods.
</summary>

The text describes a method for securing a computing device by granting access to native resources of an operating system to a managed library with a validated digital certificate, while denying access to native resources to a managed application without a valid digital certificate.
